The basic idea of the book is that science can build an evidence-based foundation for human morals. (That is, atttitudes, policies, social environments, etc. that improve or maintain the well-being of intelligent beings. "Well-being" referring to the health, happiness and similar beneficial aspects of material beings, it doesn't claim to deal with immaterial beings people may believe in.)Keep in mind, I was sympathetic to the book's concept from the beginning, but I may have expressed things differently or varied on emphasis in places. The focus on the material world may make religious people think it is incomplete, although there is much overlap between what is considered "right" and "wrong" by major religions and secular governments. To a large extent, where non-theocratic governments and religions differ are areas where most religious people would consider to be private matters between the individual and their god (they don't expect the government to arrest people for eating on religious fast days or such). Of course, there are some issues such as abortion where religious organizations may try to enact laws consistent with their religous doctrines. From a secular point of view, there may be a need to clarify aspects of such matters, such as what organic matter deserves the legal protections of a human being. If a person intentionally destroys a unit of donated blood, is it murder because human cells die? What if the blood donor has died, so the blood is the last living part of that human? If not, when does an embryo / fetus become different? It may be tricky to define what makes a protected human life, but it would provide a clear basis for such decisions - and a basis which doesn't simply quote the assertions of one of the various differeing religions.The author may at times be sharper than needed in criticizing religion. But I appreciate the basic points. Science at least attempts to establish a solid basis for what it puts forward, while religous people feel no more need than having a gut feeling something is right. Numerous cases are available of religion refusing (at least for extanded periods of tiem) to accept evidence contrary to ancient texts. Religious wars, inquisitions, discrimination and such have been used to impose religion on others.I agree with the book's premise that scientists have been too inclined to take a cautious approach to criticizing religious practices which are contrary to human well-being. Science could use criteria of physical and emotinal well-being to guage whether Americans following an Amish lifestyle or a more modern lifestyle achieve a better level. Scientists could give an evidence-based analysis of the differing consequences of following a "be fruitful and multiply" or population growth sensitive approach. It shouldn't be necessary to say all religious practices are indistinguishable in impact on human lives (or to be quiet or vague on the issue).One of the arguments others use against the book's advocacy of building a scientifically-based morality of human well-being is that humans need the religious-based morallity that is current today to limit some harmful actions. Even assuming it would be unwise to weaken religious morality in the short-term, that doesn't seem a reason not to try to construct something better to take over in the future.One of the things science has helped us see is that consciousness and free will are not what we've assumed or what most people would like to believe. Conscious thought is what percolates up from unconscious regions in order to help us do such things as justify ourselves to others or attempt to get others to do something. We have conscious "experience," but even that is edited on an unconscious level. For instance, your unconscious edits out the sensory data which results from the blinking of your eyes. To one degree or another, when the unconscious lets the conscious know what it wants or intends, the conscious mind can try to veto it; but since the conscious is only the tip of the iceberg, a "conscious veto" may really be one part of the unconscious vetoing another part. I don't think the author directed these considerations enough in his discussion of religion. The actions of individuals who perceive themselves as acting upon religious beliefs have consequences regardless of whether the religion is truly the cause or just a post-hoc rationalization. However, understanding to what degree the motives are actually something else disguised in religious garb in order to justify to others could lead us to a different approach to dealing with it.

I find myself somehow conflicted about a book that I agree with virtually from cover to cover. I appreciate the message that 'moral truths exist'; that morality can be discussed from a logical, fact based, proof supported, point of view seems obvious, but is still an argument that in our society and time needs to be made and Harris makes a good case. I personally had two issues, (1) it felt like preaching to the converted in my case - which is more about me -, and (2) large chunks of the persuasive text seemed to be more about Harris himself than about the ideas and it's support.In order to convince the reader that logic and science can and should be utilized in the efforts of morality, Harris has to also make the case against the current 'owners' of the moral territory - religious groups/individuals - and while I believe this is exceedingly well reasoned, I doubt whether someone who is not predisposed to such arguments will accept them. Because most religions conceive of their morality as a matter of being obedient to the word of God (generally for the sake of receiving supernatural reward), their precepts often have nothing to do with maximizing well-being in this world. Religious believers can, therefore, assert the immortality of contraception, masturbation, homosexuality,etc., without ever feeling obliged to argue that these practices actually cause suffering. They can also pursue aims that are flagrantly immoral, in that they needlessly perpetuate human misery, while believing that these actions are morally obligatory. This pious uncoupling of moral concern from the reality of human and animal suffering has caused tremendous harm. What Harris is essentially trying to propose is a philosophy on how we should act in order to propagate and cultivate 'well-being' for self and society; he is attempting to teach people to think in a scientific manner about things that we traditionally have been taught is not to be thought of in such terms. Believe a proposition because it is well supported be theory and evidence; believe it because it has been experimentally verified; believe it because a generation of smart people have tried their best to falsify it and failed; believe it because it is true (or seems so). This is an effort I believe worth while. Conversation is key and I think this is the real goal for Harris, to continue to be part of the discussion and make incremental movement in the direction of well supported decisions in the realm of morality. He believes that science and the scientific method has too long surrendered the moral ground to religion, and the question may be at this point and in this climate whether the scientific viewpoint will even be allowed a seat at the table, and on this point Harris is not immediately optimistic. At the end of Harris's very persuasive case we, the reader, seem to be dragged along while Harris exposes the scientific community for 'copping out' and not standing up for the methods and ideals it should rightfully fight for, it is a bit of an unpleasant way for the text to end, but perhaps also legitimate defense of his stance - ugly, but necessary I suppose.

The book starts with two premise: 1) Some people have better lives than others, and (2) These differences are related, in some lawful and not entirely arbitrary way, to states of the human brain and to states of the world.The logical place to start then is with his first premise: Some people have better lives than others.To accept this as a premise I would have to know what "better" means. There might be someone who spent his whole life sitting in alpine meadows painting flowers, whilst someone else spent his life growing rice and raising nine children. What does better mean? Or more importantly, what does Sam Harris mean by "better" in this context?I'm not saying that there are no differences, I'm asking how do we determine whether Harris' premise is correct? How do we know whether someone else's life is "better" than our own? For example, suppose I could measure in some way the quotient of my life and it comes to a. I think Sam Harris is saying that in principle there is someone who's quotient is >a. He isn't saying we have to be able to identify that person, or know who they are or how they lived their life. He is asking us to accept that in principle this person does exist or has existed.Well, in that case I'm not sure I can accept the premise. I don't think that it is possible for a person to know that a better life exists. I am able to observe that my neighbour has had and is having a very different life than mine, but by what metric is it possible for me to know that it is "better" than mine? The impossibility of answering this question tells me that it is not safe to agree with Harris' premise.Suppose, though, that isn't what Harris meant by "better". Suppose that he doesn't mean better for me as an individual, he means better for society. It's not about whether painting flowers or raising children is more fun for the individual it's about which of those is better for society.In which case raising children is clearly better because the one thing the world needs right now is more people, right? Or what about one guy who empties rubbish bins for a living while some other guy does heart transplant operations. Which one of them is "better" for society? The question is unanswerable, and therefore the premise cannot be accepted.I think at that point Sam Harris would say that heart transplant surgery versus emptying rubbish bins is not a moral choice reflective of the real world. There is no administrator of some city health care budget debating whether to hire a heart transplant surgeon or lay off five dustbin men. He's talking about moral choices we have in the real world not artificial constructs designed to miss the point.In which case, if Sam Harris is talking about better morally for society then I reply that since morality is not universal I again am unable to accept his premise. Since one man's moral imperative is another man's abhorrent abomination by what standard is he measuring "morally better" for society as a whole? The premise cannot be accepted. And since we cannot accept the premise we don't have to bother reading the book based on it.There are no spelling mistakes in it, though.

The book is essentially a combination of soft targets and old news. The Taliban aren't an ideal moral society! Who knew? Fulfillment is to be preferred to abject misery? What revolutionary advice! Refuting religious fundamentalism and some extreme-left versions of prescriptive cultural relativism, while valid enough, is also vapid and easy work, beyond the fact that it's merely rehashing work that Harris has done better elsewhere. What is genuinely worse, however, is that Harris seems to think that religious fundamentalism and prescriptive relativism represent the only two viable alternatives to his utilitarianism-with-an-fMRI plugged into it. It's worse still that he doesn't even feel like Bentham and Mill, from whom these ideas originate, are even worthy of meaningful discussion in his book.As has been noted everywhere, Harris' attempt to conduct this end-run around the philosophical literature that he is, consciously or not, merely restating is childish, lazy, and irritating. All that he has ultimately done in his book has been to redefine consequentialist philosophy as science and then to suggest that science, and not philosophy, is what should determine human values. It's both internally incoherent as an argument and a disingenuous shock ploy to sell copies. In defending the book, Harris claims to have addressed all of these criticisms in The Moral Landscape itself. If by "addressing," we mean either indicating that he does not understand them and/or perfunctorily dismissing them (as is the case with Jonathan Haidt, whose points Harris talks straight past, among others), then surely he has. If he feels that he has competently refuted the backbreaking weight of what he is up against, then he seems alone in that belief.Any competent introduction to moral philosophy (James Rachels is a good place to start) will be much more worth your time. If you're concerned about missing out on all the science that Harris brings to bear on the topic (spoiler alert!), don't waste your time. There's passing reference to some psychology and Harris' graduate work with an fMRI. None of it is essential to his argument. The "science" in Harris' subtitle essentially translates to "anything about nature that can be known in principle." It's hard to imagine applying for a grant to fund that.

This is another book that I feel lucky to have found. The book argues why morality can and should be treated as a scientifically understandable phenomenon, rather than keeping it forever shrouded under religious doctrines or imagining it as a mysterious property of another mysterious entity called the soul. It does not claim the task will be easy, or that we will ever have a perfect theory of morality that can explain or predict all of our moral choices. However, it explains why we should still pursue the course of trying to understand it as a scientific fact, which can be understood in terms of our brain and our biological evolution.There is a very important and essential distinction between a question having an answer in principle, and actually being able to get a specific answer. For example, consider the question “how many people on this planet touched their head in the last one minute?” It is an impossibly difficult question to answer in practice, but there is no doubt the question has a precise numerical answer. While we can never determine that number, it is conceivable to perform a sample study on a small group of people and extend that to come up with an estimate. This estimated number is almost certainly going to be “wrong”, and not going to match the actual answer, but it will be less wrong than say “1” or “6 billion”. To find out if a question can be explored scientifically, we just need to make sure that an answer exists in principle, and not get bogged down by the difficulty of actually getting an answer. Also, in order to claim that we have made scientific progress in answering the question we do not need to narrow it down to a precise answer, but if we can just restrict it to a range of answers that is better than what we could do randomly, then we have already made scientific progress.When confronted with difficult questions like morality or values, we should not feel dejected because the process seems too difficult, or because we cannot get an exact answer. In this book the author convincingly argues that it is possible to treat any moral question as a universal and scientific issue. The book also argues why, neither religion nor some idea of Elan Vital can successfully explain the phenomenon of morality.

This book is bad. I don't mind Sam Harris in general, but this book is basically worthless. I won't go into all the details here because other reviewers have done so, but I've got three main complaints. Firstly, Harris ignores, strawmans, or misunderstands every philosophical position he considers or even mentions, yet he clearly thinks that he is a philosophical genius who is grasping something that is plainly obvious but somehow slipped under the noses of all these philosophers. That's definitely not happening. Sam's philosophical "argument" is awful; he just asserts that morality = wellbeing maximisation. Wow, amazing. Even if we accept this "argument", what's science got to do with it? Science can tell us how to maximise wellbeing, but it doesn't determine that morality = wellbeing. Morality = wellbeing because Sam says so. But who cares if Science can tell us how to increase wellbeing? Wouldn't anyone accept that? Touching a hot stove decreases wellbeing, drinking water regularly increases it. Again, amazing.Secondly, the book's structure was an absolute mess. Sam was introducing the book up until at least page 67 (more than a quarter of the book's length) and possibly even further than that. Why don't you stop telling me what you're going to tell me, and just tell me? Additionally, it wasn't clear at all what the latter half of the book has to do with determining values. Sam was just talking about beliefs and how religious people's beliefs interfere with their scientific abilities. Ok, and? I admit that this section was less disastrous than the first half of the book, but it wasn't particularly interesting either.And that's my third complaint. The book was pretty boring. For the most part Sam just discussed the most popular of the pop science topics, which can be found in basically any pop science book.Overall, I knew going into it that Sam's attempt to demonstrate science's determination of values would fail, but I didn't know it would fail this badly. It might have been worth reading just so that I know exactly how bad his argument is.

This book seems to mess with what, for some, was a beneficial pact of non-agression: science deals with facts, religions deal with values. And this fracture came to be on the assumption that facts and values are entities of very distinct nature. For many people both the compatibility of science and religion and the mere tolerance (without compatibility) rests in that everyone agrees on what fields science and religion are suposed to cover. Sam Harris thoroughly argues on every point made against science evaluating well being, and deciding matters of right and wrong on human experience. He makes his case against moral relativism, with a strong voice, and a lucid view of what's at stake. His vision is provocative, humanist, bright. His writting is clear and rich and part of what makes this and his other books so powerful. Something important for his critics, and he has gathered many, in both sides of the trench (religious people who think that science has nothing to say about [what] morality [should be] and secularists who, give or take a little bit, think pretty much the same). The title of this book is "The Moral Landscape". The idea, that Harris gets back to many times, is that the peaks of human flourishing may be thousands, hundreads of thousands. The ways in which humans and human societies thrive and produce hapiness and well being may be many and all equally desirable. If we were to represent it in a landscape, we would have thousands of peaks and many thousands of valeys. Sam Harris is saying that there are many ways to be right about how to make a society flourish. And many wrong ways to do it. That is the whole premise, the title of the book. Some, who have not read it or bother to understand it, may be inclined to dismiss this, just because there is no acceptance of what Sam Harris proposes: science can help determine how to get to a peak of human flourishing, how to escape from a valey, a low.

I liked this one even though I think I'd really have to read it again to follow all of the scientific arguments he makes. Harris' thesis is that, contrary of a popular belief, morality can and does exist in the absence of adherence to a religion and, in fact, perhaps as a side benefit, one avoids outdated moral pronouncements (like maybe "women should keep quiet in the churches" as well as injunctions to kill nonbelievers). Harris is a neuroscientists and wants to put forward the nation that science has much to contribute to morality. I don't disagree with that at all, but I have to say that the functional MRI studies he sites (and which he seems to be involved in conducting) were the least interesting material in this book.I suppose I am somewhere between atheist and agnostic these days, and while I appreciate many of the arguments against religion made by Dawkins and Harris and Hitchens (I haven't read the latter's book but there's some of his argument in Hitch 22), I'm most interested in facilitating an environment where one can talk about religion in something other than hushed tones and where current opinion doesn't force one to take seriously anything anyone says in the name of religion. It may be wise in many circumstances to abjure discussion of religion and politics, still with politics most of us feel pretty free expressing our opinions. I may have turned off the TV this morning when Christiane Amanpour was interviewing four new tea party Congress men and women, but I don't hesitate to disagree loudly and publicly and I don't fear the PC police telling me I can't disparage their politics.

You know what you are going to get with Sam Harris, a member of the so-called "new atheist" movement (a name he shuns). Harris' writings are direct, to the point, and based upon a clear use of critical analysis. What I like about Harris' book the most is that it breaks the illusionary lines between morality, the individual, the society, and science. While Harris is not the first to broach the subject of applying critical analysis to ethics, I would argue that he has done so in the most clear and concise way yet, here.His reliance upon his background in neuroscience is the basis for his argument and his conclusion that well-being is the ultimate goal of all sentient creatures is Aristotelian. While utility does plays a role in his writings (via his views upon religion), I would argue that it is ethical virtue that is at its foundation. Harris spends a bit of time on the nature of belief from the perspective of science that does a fine job of explaining why so many people have relied wrongly upon religious belief for their moral compass. On that note, his books points out possible problems of having those who do not view ethics from a scientific view by exemplifying Francis Collins, the head of the NIH and author of "The Language of God: A Scientist Presents Evidence for Belief". His point is well-taken.The Moral Landscape offers the reader an ethical option that makes sense, is not ethically relative, and further points out the dangers of religion to such an important topic.This is a very readable book and is fully referenced with copious notes that will lead the reader to further material.

Sam Harris has written a simple, yet extraordinarily powerful book about the "science of morality" and it is quite a revelation. He cuts through the cloudy thinking of religion and relativism to get at the heart of the problem: How do we as human beings maximize our well being? He shows how certain points of view should necessarily be ignored on specific topics like morality. He doesn't argue there is one right way to be moral, to live the good life, but that there are obvious, self evident wrong ways. He also shows how neuroscience and a growing understanding of our psychology and biology are breaking new ground in the study of how we think about facts and values, and how our brains see little to no difference between these areas. Needless to say, this goes against prevailing "common sense", which is one more thing Harris lays bare as not nearly as reliable as we might like to think. Harris provides no hard and fast answers, he is attempting to lay the foundations here. He is not, like Moses, stumbling off Mt. Sinai with stone tablets emblazoned with the "truth," he is merely sketching out how we might orient ourselves to best tackle the mountain without hoping some higher power will do the work, the thinking, for us. Refreshing and brilliant.

Harris tries to prove with this book that science should be the determining factor when it comes to making moral decisions. He claims that science is the only way we can live a truly moral life. He uses the concept of "well-being" as his ruler for evaluating morality. I found his ideas to be very interesting. His discussion of free will was quite thought-provoking. For most of the book I found him to be fair in his criticism of people of faith as well as people of science (who espouse moral relativism). However, his true color comes out towards the end of the book when discussing religion--he believes that religious people are psychologically disturbed (p. 157 in my edition).In trying to judge this book based on Harris' own premise, I kept expecting him to show me evidence of HOW science will make these moral decisions for us, but I never saw that. I think he views science as the perfect, flawless solution, but apparently he is unaware of just how many differing views there are AMONG SCIENTISTS! Choose any field (evolution, archaeology, paleontology, even math) and you will be astounded by the number of differing opinions.I appreciated many of his ideas but I remain unconvinced.

i thought this book intended to state that science can inform human well-being and moral questions, but it was hard to see that through the author's bias against religion. his argument would be stronger if it didn't get clouded up by his efforts to prove how stupid everyone else is, particularly religious people - he hides behind his skill at belittling other people's beliefs. he spends more time arguing "against" than arguing "for" anything. i finished the book wondering 'but how CAN science determine human values?' i'd say the low of the book was when he stated that he tried to persuade a friend with rational arguments via email to not commit suicide. when his friend did kill himself 4 years later, he was left with questions such as 'what did the word depression mean to him' 'are there other remedies to depression that we don't know about'. i wonder if a loving community responding in person to his friend might have been more effective than rational emails. despite all my negative responses here, i do think this book has value and i'm glad to have read it, but i think my take away will be a few anecdotes and that this author really hates religion.

Is it hyped? Sure! But is it good, as good as they say? Absolutely! A must read no doubt.Harris takes a breath and delivers a groundbreaking new perspective in the field of ethics by focusing on "wellbeing", a universal, albeit at this point in time, still murky underlying principle of moral actions. Then he establishes his second premise - that everything, that could possibly matter as far as wellbeing is concerned, is expressed through mental states in purely material human brain. And this is where science comes in, as the most reliable tool humanity has in studying reality. We, Harris argues, are obliged to turn the gaze of scientific mind to human values and decisions of right and wrong, so that we can map out the moral landscape and traverse it to a more compassionate, collaborative and flourishing peak.Filled with abundant insight in human cognition and it's relevance to our perception and thinking about what matters to us, The Moral Landscape provides a substantial addition to the collection of our knowledge about ourselves and the future of mankind.

Somewhat disappointing. Seemed rather disjointed to me. Too much diatribe against religion and not enough real description of how science could provide evidence for moral values. Digression on freewill also lost me, but it wasn't too long. This book is more just a call to possible action than a framework for that action. [3/22/2012]

Like Richard Dawkins, "I was one of those who had unthinkingly bought into the hectoring myth that science can say nothing about morals." I think everyone falls into that camp at first. I did overcome this idea a while ago, after reflecting on how the more we learn about psychology and even the sentience of other animals the more we see that ideas we once thought to be outside the realm of objective knowledge, or questions we thought unanswerable, were precisely not as we thought of them. There are many things in fact that science can inform us on, and has, that previously we thought belonged to the study of philosophy or something else. And I think morality and ethics are included among these things. Moral relativism has always had a bit of a disgusting stink to it, much like the other fashionable ideas floating around in vogue circles. Sam Harris seems to not only recognize this, but to be one of the few scientists with enough intellectual honesty and disregard for fashion to address it head on.But Harris tackles this topic much more comprehensively and interestingly than I ever thought possible, and makes a hugely compelling case that so far stands up to even the strongest scrutiny. He delivers a powerful, logically sound, reasoned assessment of morality and makes a good case for a scientific basis for it, with such clear thinking that by the end of his work, it becomes evident that anyone who doubts that future discoveries in neuroscience and psychology could ever lead to a scientific and rational approach to morality sits on the same level as those who would argue that health cannot be approached scientifically. The entire medical industry stands in stark defiance of this bizarre notion. The afterward sees Sam addressing his critics, which is something everyone in the business of developing and spreading ideas should do. He effectively refutes some of the biggest criticisms of his work.I don't always agree with Sam Harris, though my disagreements with him are rare and often pedantic, but I find him to be one of the most important public intellectuals today, for a number of reasons. His thinking is ahead of its time, proposing consistent and intelligent ideas that future generations will look back at, and say, "You mean to tell me there were people alive back then who honestly thought otherwise? People found these ideas hard to accept?" And they will laugh that our fashions, our glazed over collective stupidity, our tribalism, our taboos, our superstitions, our insecurities were the primary reasons of disagreement with Sam Harris's good ideas, and rarely, if ever, were sound reasoning and logic the cause for disagreement. Sadly, even scientists have fallen into pitiful holes of sentiment and irrationality when trying to refute Sam's theses.Sam receives a hell of a lot of flack and shit from other intellectuals and pseudointellectuals, and this seems to be caused by something that Sam cannot fix: He tends to approach ideas rationally and objectively, while virtually all of his detractors (sadly, even those with scientific credentials) are in some form limited and severely affected by emotion, attachment to comfortable notions, and tend to think with a flair of subjective populace-pleasing in their rhetoric. Sam rises above this every time, and he unfortunately pays the price for it in a society that can't quite accept bluntness and honesty. This wouldn't be the case if many of his ideas didn't fly in the face of habits and ideological phantasms that our societies have stubbornly refused to let die. Strong ideas that move us forward are rarely comfortable and are never easy. I see Harris as one of the few people alive contributing to the public discourse with these kinds of ideas.Edit: I've amended this review to include more concrete examples of what Sam discusses, as encouraged in the comments below.What Sam's proposing isn't that science currently has all the answers to moral questions, or that it ever will have all the answers, which the subtitle of his book seems to suggest. He isn't saying, "Here is the science that shows us which morality is right." He's saying, "Moral questions will, in time, be able to be scrutinized scientifically instead of merely philosophically, with a more objective treatment than the relativistic way we look at them now," because science will allow us to develop a better understanding of how different behaviors and actions result in positive or negative outcomes, in terms of conscious experience. The metric he proposes to measure this is human and animal well-being. An obvious response to this idea is that there doesn't seem to be a universally easy and clear way to define well-being, which makes this kind of metric useless. But by the same token, there is no clear and universal way to evaluate what health means, but this doesn't stop an entire scientific industry being devoted to it and understanding it, and it doesn't stop most people from realizing health is important, or that there are objectively right and wrong answers in how to maximize one's health. In the ways we understand health as a spectrum of bad to good, despite having definitive answers as to what exactly always constitutes good health vs bad health, we can also understand well-being, with some states objectively better than others: Living comfortably and content and having all your needs accounted for, not feeling any emotional or physical pain, no suffering, VS. Living in constant fear, constant pain, experiencing frequent loss, etc.. These are two extremes along a spectrum, but they can objectively be understood to differ in value. The basic principle behind Sam's idea is that with advancements in neuroscience, physiology, and psychology, and with better understandings of how measurable brain activity corresponds to human feeling, or emotion, we can first of all develop a more objective and measurable basis for well-being, and can then find out what actions or conditions allow humans to reach the higher levels of this spectrum. This entails eliminating the intellectual crutch of cultural context and moral relativism in trying to justify how actions that are obviously at odds with human or animal well-being can be moral, because the most basic facts about human (and all about animal) flourishing transcend culture. So, he uses various examples throughout the book to support the assertions he makes. He states that once we think about morality in terms of well-being, it becomes easy to discern a moral hierarchy across human societies. He uses the Dobu islanders as an example to illustrate a group toward the bottom of this hierarchy, as they are a deeply violent culture, with jealousy, superstition, widespready distrust, "sorcery", and greed running rampant through their society, without any minimization by social institutions. Their beliefs in superstitions and magic often result in death and suffering, while even the act of someone dying in their society can result in that person's closest relatives being blamed as magical accomplices in that person's death, which leads to further violence. Everyone fears everyone else, because trust is non-existent, and cooperation even seems to be minimal and based only on fear of pain or curse. They believe that spells can be purchased and traded, and that certain magical people among them hold all control of illness and resources.It must be objectively stated that the Dobu have patently false beliefs about reality, about science, about medicine. But a moral relativist would argue that they can't possibly have wrong beliefs about morality. And some would even argue that despite all these massive cultural differences, the Dobu must still love one another and have compassion for one another just like we do. But the reality of the matter is that love, compassion, trust, and other states of the human mind have distinct neurophysiology, which we are getting better and better grips on with advancements in science, that will allow us to show that, objectively, the Dobu do not likely possess the same well-being as people in other societies. And this fact will be due to their position on the moral hierarchy. The idea of moral science isn't to say that there is always a single right answer to a moral question, or even that we will ever be capable of knowing every possible answer to a moral question. A more fundamental principle in Sam's thesis is that all questions of "good" and "evil" boil down to the possibility of experiencing values like happiness, suffering, despair, etc... So saying an act is morally necessary, evil, or blameless, is to make claims about its consequences in the lives of conscious creatures. And that even within religion, consequences and conscious states are the foundation of all values. He uses a Muslim suicide bomber as an example to illustrate this, as someone who most might think is not following this mode of consequentialist thinking when committing an immoral act. But in fact, he is thinking this way, because the consequences of his actions, real and imaginary, are the entire point. He assumes he will secure a place for himself in Paradise, and for seventy of his closest relatives. Although it can easily be argued his morals are flawed and his thinking is flawed, what he believes is a moral act is based upon his understanding of consequence and experience. Here is some reasoning he uses when discussing whether or not we could ever be "right" about what is right and wrong. Joshua Greene, who has done neuroimaging research on morality, says that there is nothing that could make a moral claim true or false. Harris disagrees and says:Moral view A is truer than moral view B if A entails a more accurate understanding of the connections between human thoughts/intentions/behavior and human well-being. Does forcing women and girls to wear burqas make a net positive contribution to human well-being? Does it produce happier boys and girls? Does it produce more compassionate men or more contented women? Does it make for better relationships between men and women, between boys and their mothers, or between girls and their fathers? These are questions that could be answered, particularly with the help of science.

I've read several books from the so called 'new atheists'. I've found that on books concerning religious matters, I mostly hate their books. Its not that I even care that they're atheist or not, I'm all for reading atheist arguments. I recently read Sagan's agnostic lecture book and loved it, but I have a problem with they way the present their material, they take the most absurd extreme examples of religion and throw them out as the norm. Most of these examples would infuriate the vast majority of religious people, I often feel that their arguments are more polemics and anti religious propaganda than actual thought out reasons of whether there is or isn't a deity. Sadly it seems the more I read their book reviews on sites like amazon, it seems that many of their followers take the same intolerant stances. With that being said, for the most part I like Dawkin's evolution books, so I figured that its worth a shot reading Harris's book on using science to determine morality. Sadly it seems the 'science' part of the book is pretty sparse and its just more of the same.I think I sort of agreed with the idea of this book before I started reading, basically that we should use science to help determine our morals and actions. I wouldn't be exclusive to science though, but if something can be tested and proved to be useful then I'm all for it. I actually don't think that religious values should be the norm for our laws, for example even though you could argue that Paul (see Romans in the bible) and orthodox Christianity are reasons for requiring marriage to be between a man and a woman, but if you remove the religious aspect of it, I think that most people with an open mind would allow gay marriage (I wonder if one day we'll look back on these things the same way we look back on racial issues). I think issues such as stem cell research or abortion should be discussed and both sides presented. I also think we're getting overpopulated and so I'm all for things like using condoms for birth control.My first surprise with this book is just how sparse the references to scientific studies are, I guess at this time there just aren't that many or Harris didn't want to mention them because it might quickly outdate his book. There are a few studies mentioned every now and then, but for the most part its more of him trying to show how religion is a bad way to determine morality, how there can be objective morality and that science can reach it (although few examples of what he means). For the most part I was okay with this, I didn't agree with everything he presented and don't think that some issues aren't easy to agree on, but I didn't hate the book up to this point.Then came the chapter on religion which basically made me want to put the book down (had this been earlier in the book, I would have stopped reading, but by then I was already too committed to stop). Harris didn't grow up religious and I think he fails just to understand what its like for a believer to believe. Take for example, at one part of the book he mocks belief in Jesus, one of his comments mocks the idea that Jesus can hear a billion prayers at once. Logically if Jesus was only a man then this is a pretty good argument. Now regardless of what you actually believe, pretend you're a christian who believes that all things were created through Jesus (meaning that a billion billion galaxies were created by him, see John 1:1-3), then its not hard to see why a Christian would have no problem believing that Jesus could hear a billion prayers at once, its relatively a simple task compared to creating the universe. Obviously mocking someone for accepting prayer to a being like this is pretty absurd. Of course if you believe that Jesus was just a man then he couldn't hear just one prayer let alone billions. Later he comes to a rant against Francis Collins, the person appointed by Obama as the director of the National Institutes of Health. Basically, he's pissed that Collins, someone that hold religious convictions is appointed to such a high position, and he basis this on religious grounds. He admits that Collins holds the same position as him on issues like evolution or stem cell research, but he can't stand the fact that Collins prayed before taking this position. Now here is my point, I hope that one day we can get to a point of racial, ethnic and religious tolerance for all people. For example a place where the next president candidate is elected on his views and past voting precedent and not on something like his religious stance. I think it is wrong that if someone is an open atheist/agnostic, he doesn't stand a chance of being the president regardless of his credentials. I'm not sure Harris would agrees on the opposite, I think if he had his way only atheists would be qualified. Take Collins, Harris seems to attack someone whom does seem to be qualified for the position almost solely on his religious beliefs. Harris's comments about Collins seems to have pissed off some fellow atheists, and Harris goes on to reprint their letters / newspaper columns. These remarks from the others seem logical to me (more so than the majority of the book), they think Harris should back down, not attack someone based on Christianity, that Harris and the new atheists are doing more harm than good on issues like evolution (I've seen this first hand where someone will deny evolution because it makes you an atheist like Dawkins). Harris ignores this because truthfully his goal isn't getting things like modern science / evolution accepted but its to remove religion. Which brings me to my final point, who is the audience of this book? Harris seems to try to piss everyone off, religious, philosophers, and fellow scientists. It seems the audience is the very limited to his new atheist followers. This is the biggest problem with the book, if you want to see change happen you have to convince a much broader audience, we live in a democracy and a majority of the population does still believe in a deity and Harris tries to be elite and attack the masses and expects real change to happen, but the only thing which will happen is they'll further oppose his view. This major thing makes the book pretty pointless, Harris is just trying to convince his small (relatively) audience and no one else. With everything being said, I'm done reading these new atheist books for now, I'll get my atheist / agnostic arguments elsewhere. I don't have time to read intolerant Christian fundamentalists, I don't have time to read their atheist counterparts either.

The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly.First of all, I have to admit that I am a devout Christian and I completely disagree with the philosophy of Scientism. And although everyone reads and learns with some element of bias, I tried to read this with much of an open mind as possible. With that being said, I found a lot of good and enjoyed The Moral Landscape. I respect Harris and applaud his bravery on the topic. However, there were also many elements of his book where I thought his rationale was shaky and perhaps even contradictory. And some parts that, to me, were downright absurd. I'll discuss all these things under the topics of "Good, bad, and ugly".THE GOOD: While Harris and I sit rather far away on many spectrum of thought, one of the most important beliefs is one that we both share, which is the praxis of Ethics. Harris cares a lot about human suffering. He is not the type who merely ponders ethics in an ivory tower. He stresses action - and this is vital regardless of one's worldview. And while it seems that Christians and Atheists rarely play nice with each other, I'd rather go to a party with a room full of Atheistic doers than Christian thinkers. Another thing that Harris and I have in common is our beliefs in moral absolutism. Harris is bold in his moral views that typically don't fit with many that run in his circle. He unapologetically combats the views of moral relativism with articulation and vigor. I'm sure this puts poor Sam Harris in a situation where he gets heat from both sides, so I admire his convictions. I think it's sad when people determine the quality of a book based on how much of it they agreed or disagreed with. The Moral Landscape had a plethora of views and ideas that while I can respect I completely disagree with. This does not take away from the fact that it was a decently written book. He articulated his thoughts with a lot of detail and was easily understandable thanks to a lot of his analogies. He was humble enough to list plenty of argument against his finds and argued them with relative respect. Regardless of my belief, I learned a lot, as he covered a variety of tidbits in various studies like ontology, epistemology, psychology, natural science, etc. Harris did not change my mind on many things, but I am ultimately better for reading this book.THE BAD: As much as I liked this book, there were a few disappointing things. First off, the subtitle should not have been "How Science can determine values," it should have been "Why Science can determine values". The book was 95% argument and defense and about 5% how. This was a little disappointing. And in his many, many arguments, there were a few that were very weak and even contradictory. Now, in Harris' defense, this field is still very young and he was honest enough to admit that he did not have all the answers. And I'm honest enough to say that perhaps I interpreted some of thoughts incorrectly. After all, I'm but a journeyman intellectual trying to comprehend the unique perspective of a neuroscientist. But there has been a trend among many readers that have seen the same pattern of inconsistency in his arguments. Another bad aspect - Harris, just like in his other books, couldn't suppress his inner angry Atheist. But what would a Sam Harris book be without a little vitriol against Christians? Now, as a Christian I must say that he is correct on a lot of his views regarding morality and religion. Moral absolutism, mixed with religious views can sometimes create incredibly dogmatic people that refuse to see reason because, after all, they're arguing on behalf of God. I'll be the first to admit that throughout history many Christians have been ignorant and dangerous with their ethics that are based on poor interpretations of scripture. But it's important to not throw the baby out with the bathwater. Harris tends to focus on the stupidity of a small yet vocal minority in order to discredit all aspects of faith. And while Harris mostly writes with objectivity when talking about Science, he tends to show a little more pathos and personal bias when talking about Christianity. THE UGLY: There were a few unfortunate points in the book. Harris had me respecting all of his thoughts until he stated his belief that we have no free will and are nothing but slaves to the neurons in our heads. With this belief, I felt that a lot of his views came crashing down like a house of cards. Harris tried to distinguish differences between this view and fatalism, but I feel it's incredibly hard to do this. It was this point that he should have explained more. But his arguments were absurdly shallow. Another ugly part of the book was its often feel of arrogance that is characteristic of the new Atheist movement. Harris, as well as many of his drinking buddies, tend to argue through nothing but the small lens of Methodism, play Scientism as a trump card, and intellectually write off anyone who thinks otherwise. Harris does not go as far as some like Hawking who proclaims that Philosophy is dead, but his arrogance in Scientism appears to be evident. He at one point talks about those who argue things that they have little knowledge of, such as Christian Apologists that debate Evolution. But Harris is guilty of this as well. Harris also implies the notion that Scientists are always humble and honest and objective. Bull. This ever-growing attitude that Scientism is completely impartial and unbiased and humble and all about facts is absurd and laughable. I would question anyone's rationality and/or honesty who says that the theories in Steven Hawking's new book was based on pure scientific observation without an iota of his strong belief that God doesn't exist. With all that being said, I am glad I read the Moral Landscape. Again, regardless of my extremely opposing views, the most important take away from this book is a call to moral action that ends human suffering. And while my particularism views majorly clash with Harris, I do believe that Science should play a role in ethics. Science can give some incredibly valuable information on the subject - it just can't be the only thing determining it.

On the face of it, I am the perfect, most receptive audience for this book. I love Harris's podcast (his guests and conversations are fascinating) and I already think that we should look to science to help us figure out what "good" means for human beings as we tackle tough ethical questions. I was pretty disappointed in the final product, unfortunately. Most importantly of my criticisms is that Harris claims far too quickly that his science-based morality overcomes the "is/ought" problem. It doesn't. It can't. Claiming that science does overcome this foundational-to-ethics problem makes him overreach on his general conclusion that science can and should determine ethical norms. If he instead had said that science can and should inform our ethical norms, I would be all on board. Even though I think he overreached with his conclusion, there is still a LOT of good stuff to consider and take seriously in this book for anyone thinking through the thorny issues of how to discover and construct the ethical norms that best allow us to navigate this difficult, complicated thing called relational living, with as much good and as little harm as possible.

The basic idea of this book is interesting and compelling.
